questions.text:
Identify the primary air pollutants among the following options:


	Carbon Monoxide (CO)
	Methane (CH4)
	Sulfur Dioxide (SO2)
	Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2)
	Ozone (O3)
	Lead (Pb)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C

Explanation:

Air Pollutants are substances in the air that can adversely affect human health, the environment, and the climate. They can be solid particles, liquid droplets, or gases.

Air pollutants are typically categorised into:

  • Primary Pollutants are emitted directly from a source into the atmosphere.
  • Secondary Pollutants are not emitted directly. Instead, they form in the atmosphere through chemical reactions between primary pollutants and other atmospheric components.

Primary

Secondary
  • Carbon Monoxide (CO)
  • Sulfur Dioxide (SO₂)
  • Nitrogen Oxides (NOₓ)
  • Particulate Matter (PM₁₀, PM₂.₅)
  • Volatile Organic Compounds
  • Lead (Pb)
  • Ozone (O₃)
  • Methane (CH4)
  • Sulfates
  • Nitrates
  • Secondary Particulate Matter

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of air pollution?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D

Explanation:

Indicators of air pollution:

Sulphur Dioxide (SO2)
  • A gas emitted from burning fossil fuels and industrial processes; causes respiratory problems and acid rain.
  • Most important indicator of air pollution.

Soiling Index
  • Measures the accumulation of particulate matter (dirt) on surfaces.
  • Specific amount of air is filtered through a filter paper and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter.

Grit and Dust Measurement
  • Quantifies the concentration of dust, grit deposits and small particulate matter present in the air.

Coefficient of Haze
  • Measures smoke and other aerosols in air.

Air Pollution Index (API)
  • Composite measure of overall air quality based on concentrations of various pollutants.

McArdle's index is an indicator to measure:

  • Air comfort.
  • Predictable sweat rate in 4 hours.

questions.text: A patient resides in an area with an AQI of 250. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D

Explanation:

Air Quality Index (AQI):

  • A numerical scale used to describe the quality of the air in a specific location.
  • An indicator of air pollution.
  • It is given by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB)
  • AQI doesn't measure Carbon Dioxide

Components of Air Quality Index (AQI)

  1. Sulphur dioxide, Nitrogen dioxide, and Carbon monoxide levels
  2. Ozone level
  3. Particulate matter 2.5 and 10
  4. Measures Lead, Ammonia, Chlorofluorocarbons, & Hydrogen sulphide levels etc.

questions.text: Which of the following is best measured by McArdle's Index?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C

Explanation:

The McArdle’s index measures the predictable 4 hours sweat rate.

McArdle’s index:

  • Measures air comfort and predictable 4 hours Sweat Rate (P4SR).
  • P4SR classifies thermal comfort levels as:
    • Comfort zone: 1 to 3 litres.
    • Just tolerable: 3 to 4.5 litres.
    • Intolerable: >4.5 litres.

 

OTHER OPTIONS:

Cooling Power of air (Option A)
  • Determines the capacity of the atmosphere to dissipate the metabolite heat generated by humans.
  • Includes 3 components: Air temperature, Air humidity and low air velocity.
  • Measured by a Kata thermometer.

Heat Stress Index (Option B)
  • The ratio of evaporation required to maintain heat balance to maximum evaporation maintained in a particular environment is expressed as a percentage.
  • Related to body sweating.
  • It ranges from 0 to 100.
    • Severe heat strain: 40 to 60
    • Very severe heat strain: 70 to 90
    • The upper limit of heat tolerance: 100.

Effective Temperature
  • Measures heat stress index.
  • This includes air temperature, air humidity, and airflow/air velocity and cooling power of air

Corrected effective temperature (Option D)
  • A better indicator of air comfort than effective temperature.
  • Includes 4 components: Air temperature, air humidity, air velocity, Mean radiant heat ( i.e Effective temperature+ mean radiant heat)
  • A Globe thermometer is an instrument used to measure this.

questions.text: What is the instrument's name, shown below, for measuring low air velocity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

Kata thermometer:

 
  • Identification: It has a narrow and thin bulb that is red-coloured.
  • Used to measure
    • Low air velocity.
    • Cooling power of air (rarely) as it does not provide reliable estimates.
  • The cooling power of air is an indicator of air comfort.
  • A dry Kata reading of more than 6 and a wet Kata reading of more than 20 indicate thermal comfort.

 

Globe thermometer:

 
  • Identification: A thick and wide bulb is present.
  • Used to measure corrected effective temperature or radiant heat.

Wet bulb hygrometer:

  • Used to measure the relative humidity of the atmosphere.

 

Anemometer:

  • Used to measure air velocity in the early days.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the following device are not true?



 


	It measures radiant heat flux.
	It is used to assess thermal comfort in indoor environments.
	It measures a lower temperature than the ordinary air temperature
	It measures air temperature directly.
	It is not used to measure the cooling power of air.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A

Explanation:

Globe thermometers commonly used to evaluate thermal comfort in indoor environments represent the average temperature of the room surface, including radiant heat exchange.

Air quality measurement

Globe thermometer
  • Thick, wide and hollow copper bulb coated with matt black paint.
  • Used to measure corrected effective temperature or mean radiant heat (convection/ transferred heat). (STATEMENT 1)
  • While the globe thermometer does measure a component of air temperature, it primarily measures the mean radiant temperature, which is a combined effect of air temperature, radiant heat, and air movement (Statment 4).
  • Registers higher temperature than the ordinary air temperature (STATEMENT 3)
  • Influenced by air movement velocity and temperature
  • A wet globe thermometer consists of a blackened copper sphere completely covered with wet black cloth that exchanges heat by conduction, convection, evaporation and radiation (like sweating).

 

The cooling power of the air is measured by a kata thermometer (Statement 5).

questions.text: Which of the following is true about global warming?

choices.text: It is primarily caused by increased solar radiation.
Paris Agreement aimed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in developed countries
Kyoto Protocol called for a 50% reduction in greenhouse emissions.
Water vapour is one of the important greenhouse gases.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D

Explanation:

Global warming:

  • The rise in the earth’s temperature is primarily due to human activities increasing greenhouse gases. (OPTION A)
  • Important greenhouse gases: Water vapour, Carbon dioxide (mc), Nitrous oxide, Methane, Ground level ozone (OPTION D)
  • Chlorofluorocarbons decrease the stratosphere ozone layer and enter harmful radiations released from the sun.
  • Kyoto protocol:
    • An initiative for climate protection and control of global warming
    • 90% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions (Option C)
    • Promote renewable energy sources
  • Paris Agreement:
    • To control greenhouse gas emissions and promote renewable energy sources.
    • Improve air quality index.
    • Aimed for both developing and developed nations (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a type of mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A

Explanation:

Types of Ventilation

Natural (Option B, C and D)

Mechanical (Option A )

1. Wind:

  • Perflation: wind blows through a room
  • Aspiration: wind bypasses and exerts a suction
  • Cross-ventilation.

2. Diffusion: Air passes through small openings

3. Temperature Inequality: Air movement from high to low density due to temperature difference.

1. Exhaust: air is extracted outside by exhaust fans

2. Plenum: fresh air blown inside by centrifugal fans

3. Balanced: Combination of exhaust and plenum

4. Air conditioning: control of all air factors affecting physical and chemical conditions of the atmosphere

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements regarding ideal housing standards.


	Built-up area of houses should not exceed 2/3rd in urban areas
	Roof of a house should be at least 10 meters in height
	Window area should be at least 1/5th of the floor area
	Cattle sheds should be at least 25 feet from the housing area
	Door and window should be at least 2/5th of the floor area
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C

Explanation:

Recommended housing standards:

Urban:

  • Site: elevated from surroundings, pollution-free, not near mosquito-breeding sources
  • Set Back: built-up area should not exceed 2/3rd in urban areas (statement 1)
  • Floor: plinth height should be 2-3 ft; if mud, should be crack-free
  • Walls: should use 9-inch bricks, low heat transmittance
  • Roof: should be more than 10 ft, low heat transmittance (statement 2)
  • Rooms: as per standards to avoid overcrowding
  • Floor Area :
    • living area: at least 100 sq. ft. for 1 person, 120 sq. ft for >1 person
    • room: as per standards to avoid overcrowding

Windows: at least 2 windows per room, height not more than 3 ft, should be ⅕ th of floor area (statement 3), ⅖ th of the floor area with doors combined (statement 5)

  • Lighting: Daylight factor >1% over half of the floor area
  • Kitchen: well lit, dust & smoke-free, good water supply
  • Privy: accessible, with water facilities
  • Adequate waste disposal facilities
  • Facilities for washing and bathing with proper water supply

Rural:

  • At least 2 living rooms
  • The built-up area should not exceed 1/3rd in rural
  • Windows: at least 10% of floor area
  • Proper water, sanitation and waste disposal facilities
  • Cattle sheds should be 25 feet away from housing areas (statement 4)

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered overcrowding?

choices.text: 1 person living in a floor space of 65 sq.ft.
2 persons aged 7 of opposite gender in the same room
A child aged 8 years living in a floor space of 45 sq.ft.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2 persons aged 7 of opposite gender in the same room

Explanation:

Overcrowding is considered when 2 persons of age 9 or more of the opposite gender, not husband and wife, live in the same room.

Overcrowding:

A situation where more people live in a space less than recommended can affect their

  • physical (poor hygiene standards, spread of infections).
  • psychosocial health (difficult sleep, inadequate privacy).

Accepted standards:

Persons Per Room

Floor Space (1 sq.m. = 10 sq.ft.)
  • 1 room - 2 persons
  • 2 rooms - 3 persons
  • 3 rooms - 5 persons (option A)
  • 4 rooms - 7 persons
  • 5 or more rooms - 10 persons (2 per each room)
  • Not recommended: <50 sq.ft.
  • ½ person : 50-70 sq. ft. (option D)
  • 1 person: 70-90 sq. ft. (option B)
  • 1 ½ persons: 90-100 sq. ft.
  • 2 persons : >110 sq. ft.
  • A baby <12 months of age are not counted as a person
  • A child aged 1-10 years is counted as half a unit (option D)

questions.text: A 31-year-old male who wants to set up a radio diagnostic centre consults you regarding the possible health hazards his radio technicians might face. What is the ideal thickness of lead aprons you advise him to provide his employees that should prevent the employees from radiation hazards?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  D) 0.5 mm

Explanation:

The ideal thickness of lead aprons to prevent the technicians from radiation hazards is 0.5 mm.

Radiation exposure is hazardous (dose-dependent), ranging from acute radiation sickness up to genetic mutations, fetal anomalies and carcinogenesis.

RADIATION DOSE

BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS

<5 rad
  • No adverse effects
 

5-150 rad
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Mild haematological changes
 

150-1100 rad
  • Bone marrow failure (anaemia, infections, bleeding tendency - might require bone marrow transplantation), death occur in years.
 

1100-2000 rad
  • Gastrointestinal destruction in addition (death almost always occurs in a few weeks)

>2000 rad
  • Muscle and brain damage (death occurs in days)
